objective: Understand the role of agriculture in the economy.
content: Agriculture as a source of food, employment, and foreign exchange. Challenges facing regional agriculture.
specific_objectives: Define agriculture and its branches
Discuss the importance of agriculture to the Caribbean
Identify the major problems facing regional agriculture
Explain the role of government and regional organizations (CARDI, IICA) in agriculture
Identify various career opportunities in the agricultural sector

objective: Apply business principles to agricultural production.
content: Records, budgeting, marketing of agricultural products, and cooperatives.
specific_objectives: Explain the importance of keeping farm records (physical and financial)
Prepare a simple farm budget
Discuss the factors influencing the market for agricultural products
Explain the functions of agricultural marketing boards
Describe the role and benefits of agricultural cooperatives

objective: Manage soil and plants for optimal yield.
content: Soil composition, fertility, land preparation, and crop management (vegetables and fruits).
specific_objectives: Analyze the physical and chemical properties of soil
Calculate soil pH and explain its importance to crop growth
Describe various methods of soil conservation
Explain the stages of land preparation (clearing, ploughing, harrowing)
Discuss the cultivation of a specific vegetable and fruit crop (planting to harvesting)
Identify common pests and diseases and their control methods

objective: Apply principles of animal science to livestock production.
content: Ruminant and non-ruminant digestive systems, breeds, and management of poultry, pigs, or rabbits.
specific_objectives: Distinguish between ruminant and non-ruminant digestive systems
Identify breeds of livestock suitable for the Caribbean
Discuss aspects of animal nutrition (rations, additives)
Describe the management practices for poultry (layers and broilers) or pigs
Explain the prevention and control of common livestock diseases
Discuss the processing and marketing of animal products

section: Section A: Living Organisms in the Environment
objective: Understand the fundamental structure of living organisms.
content: Cell types, organelles, and the hierarchy of biological organization.
specific_objectives: Compare the structures of unspecialized plant and animal cells
Match cell organelles (nucleus, mitochondria, chloroplasts, ribosomes) to their functions
Relate the structure of specialized cells (sperm, egg, root hair, xylem) to their functions
Discuss the levels of organization: cell, tissue, organ, organ system, organism

objective: Analyze how organisms obtain and use energy.
content: Photosynthesis in plants and human nutrition (digestion and enzymes).
specific_objectives: Explain the process and significance of photosynthesis
Identify the parts of the human digestive system and their functions
Explain the role of enzymes in digestion (amylase, protease, lipase)
Discuss the importance of a balanced diet and the effects of malnutrition
Describe the process of aerobic and anaerobic respiration

objective: Understand how substances are moved within organisms.
content: Transpiration and translocation in plants; the circulatory system in humans.
specific_objectives: Explain the mechanisms of transpiration and translocation in plants
Identify the components of human blood and their functions
Describe the structure and function of the human heart and blood vessels
Explain the process of gaseous exchange in humans and plants
Discuss the role of the skin and kidneys in excretion and osmoregulation

objective: Analyze the mechanisms of heredity and the evolution of species.
content: Mitosis, meiosis, genetic crosses, and the theory of natural selection.
specific_objectives: Distinguish between mitosis and meiosis
Predict the results of monohybrid crosses (genotype and phenotype ratios)
Explain the concepts of dominance, recessiveness, and co-dominance
Discuss the significance of genetic variation
Explain the theory of evolution by natural selection

section: Section 1: The Indigenous Peoples and the Europeans
objective: Analyze the social and political organization of indigenous peoples and the impact of European arrival.
content: Kalinago, Taino, and Maya cultures. The encounter and the systems of forced labor (Encomienda).
specific_objectives: Describe the social, economic, and political systems of the Taino and Kalinago
Explain the social and political organization of the Maya
Identify the motives for European exploration and expansion
Discuss the impact of European arrival on the indigenous populations (demographic collapse)
Describe the Encomienda system and its effects

subsection: The Sugar Revolution and Slave Trade
objective: Analyze the development of the sugar industry and the transatlantic slave trade.
content: Transition from tobacco to sugar, the Middle Passage, and the organization of the plantation.
specific_objectives: Explain the reasons for the change from tobacco to sugar production
Discuss the organization of the Transatlantic Slave Trade
Describe the conditions of the Middle Passage
Analyze the social and economic structure of a typical sugar plantation
Explain the role of enslaved labor in the production of sugar

subsection: Rebellion and the End of Slavery
objective: Evaluate the methods used by the enslaved to gain freedom.
content: Forms of resistance (Marronage, revolts), the abolitionist movement, and the Emancipation Act.
specific_objectives: Distinguish between non-insurrectionary and insurrectionary forms of resistance
Compare the causes and consequences of major slave revolts (Haiti, Barbados, Jamaica)
Explain the various factors contributing to the abolition of the slave trade and slavery
Describe the apprenticeship system and its failures
Analyze the significance of the 1833 Emancipation Act

objective: Analyze the challenges and changes in Caribbean society after slavery.
content: Free villages, indentured labor systems, and the emergence of civil society.
specific_objectives: Identify the challenges faced by the newly freed people
Explain the development of free villages in the Caribbean
Analyze the introduction and impact of indentured labor (Indians, Chinese, Portuguese)
Describe the role of the Church and education in post-emancipation society
Discuss the Crown Colony system of government

objective: Analyze the movement towards independence and regional cooperation.
content: The labor movements of the 1930s, the West Indies Federation, and the achievement of independence.
specific_objectives: Evaluate the causes and consequences of the labor riots of the 1930s
Explain the role of local political leaders and trade unions
Discuss the successes and failures of the West Indies Federation
Trace the steps towards the achievement of independence in various Caribbean territories
Discuss the ongoing efforts towards regional integration (CARICOM, CSME)

subsection: States of Matter and Pure Substances
objective: Understand the nature of matter and its classifications.
content: Particulate nature of matter, states of matter, mixtures vs pure substances, and separation techniques.
specific_objectives: Describe the particulate nature of matter (atoms, molecules, ions)
Explain the differences between the states of matter in terms of kinetic energy and arrangement
Distinguish between elements, compounds, and mixtures
Identify various separation techniques (filtration, distillation, chromatography) and their applications
Differentiate between physical and chemical changes

objective: Analyze the structure of the atom and the organization of elements.
content: Atomic number, mass number, isotopes, and the periodic table (Groups and Periods).
specific_objectives: Decipher the structure of the atom: protons, neutrons, electrons
Define atomic number, mass number, and isotopes
List the characteristics of the Periodic Table
Determine electronic configurations of the first 20 elements
Analyze trends in Group 2 and Group 7 elements

objective: Understand how atoms interact to form compounds.
content: Ionic, covalent, and metallic bonding. Writing chemical formulas and balancing equations.
specific_objectives: Describe ionic bonding (electron transfer) and covalent bonding (electron sharing)
Identify properties of ionic and covalent compounds
Write chemical formulas using valency
Construct and balance chemical equations
State and apply the Law of Conservation of Mass

objective: Analyze the chemistry of carbon compounds.
content: Alkanes, Alkenes, Alcohols, and Organic Acids. Focuses on structure and reactions.
specific_objectives: Define 'Homologous Series'
Identify the general formulas and structures of alkanes and alkenes
Distinguish between saturated and unsaturated hydrocarbons
Describe the reactions of alcohols (ethanol) and organic acids (ethanoic acid)
Explain the concept of 'polmerization' (addition and condensation)

objective: Evaluate the properties and uses of inorganic substances.
content: Reactivity series, extraction of metals, and chemistry of non-metals (Nitrogen, Sulfur).
specific_objectives: Compare the physical and chemical properties of metals and non-metals
Analyze the Reactivity Series of metals
Describe the extraction of iron (Blast Furnace) and aluminum (Electrolysis)
Discuss the uses and properties of common non-metals and their compounds
Identify common gases (Oxygen, Hydrogen, Carbon Dioxide) using laboratory tests

objective: Understand the central problem of economics and its implications.
content: Focuses on the concepts of scarcity, choice, and opportunity cost. It explores how individuals and societies make decisions when faced with limited resources and unlimited wants.
specific_objectives: Define the term 'Economics'
Explain the concept of scarcity and its universality
Distinguish between 'wants' and 'needs'
Analyze the relationship between scarcity, choice, and opportunity cost
Use Production Possibility Curves (PPCs) to illustrate opportunity cost and economic growth
Identify the three fundamental economic questions: What to produce? How to produce? For whom to produce?

objective: Evaluate different ways of organizing economic activity.
content: Comparison of traditional, command (planned), free market, and mixed economic systems. Analyzes how each system answers the fundamental economic questions and allocates resources.
specific_objectives: Describe the characteristics of a traditional economy
Explain the features of a command (planned) economy
Explain the features of a free market economy
Analyze the role of the government and the private sector in a mixed economy
Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of each economic system

section: Section 2: Production, Economic Resources and Resource Allocation
objective: Identify and analyze the resources used in production.
content: Detailed study of Land, Labour, Capital, and Entrepreneurship. Explores the rewards for each factor and the concept of specialization.
specific_objectives: Define and give examples of Land, Labour, Capital, and Entrepreneurship
Identify the rewards for each factor: Rent, Wages, Interest, and Profit
Distinguish between fixed and circulating capital
Analyze factors influencing the supply and quality of labour (human capital)
Explain the importance of the entrepreneur in the production process
Describe the concept of 'specialization' or 'division of labour' and its effects on productivity

section: Section 2: Production, Economic Resources and Resource Allocation
objective: Analyze the structure of production in an economy.
content: Categorization of economic activities into primary, secondary, and tertiary sectors. Focuses on the changing importance of these sectors during economic development.
specific_objectives: Define and provide examples of activities in the primary sector
Define and provide examples of activities in the secondary sector
Define and provide examples of activities in the tertiary sector
Describe the transition of Caribbean economies from primary to service-based (tertiary) activities

objective: Explain the relationship between price and quantity demanded.
content: Analysis of the Law of Demand, demand schedules, and demand curves. Explores movements along the curve versus shifts in the curve.
specific_objectives: State the Law of Demand
Distinguish between individual demand and market demand
Identify factors that cause a shift in the demand curve (income, tastes, prices of substitutes/complements)
Distinguish between a 'change in quantity demanded' and a 'change in demand'

objective: Explain the relationship between price and quantity supplied.
content: Analysis of the Law of Supply, supply schedules, and supply curves. Explores the impact of production costs and technology on supply.
specific_objectives: State the Law of Supply
Identify factors that cause a shift in the supply curve (cost of production, technology, number of firms)
Distinguish between a 'change in quantity supplied' and a 'change in supply'

objective: Analyze how prices are determined in a market.
content: Interaction of demand and supply to determine equilibrium price and quantity. Explores the effects of shortages and surpluses.
specific_objectives: Define 'equilibrium price' and 'equilibrium quantity'
Illustrate market equilibrium using a diagram
Explain the effects of changes in demand and supply on equilibrium price and quantity
Analyze the impact of government-imposed price controls (ceilings and floors)

objective: Measure the responsiveness of demand and supply to changes in price and other variables.
content: Calculation and interpretation of Price Elasticity of Demand (PED), Income Elasticity (YED), and Price Elasticity of Supply (PES).
specific_objectives: Define and calculate PED using the formula
Distinguish between elastic, inelastic, and unitary demand
Identify factors affecting PED (availability of substitutes, time, proportion of income)
Explain the relationship between PED and total revenue
Define and interpret Income Elasticity of Demand (YED) for normal vs. inferior goods
Define and calculate Price Elasticity of Supply (PES)

section: Section 4: Market Structure and Market Failure
objective: Analyze the characteristics and behavior of firms in different market types.
content: Exploration of perfect competition, monopoly, monopolistic competition, and oligopoly. Focuses on barriers to entry and price-setting power.
specific_objectives: Describe the characteristics of Perfect Competition
Describe the characteristics of Monopoly
Distinguish between Monopolistic Competition and Oligopoly
Explain the concept of 'barriers to entry'
Compare the efficiency of perfect competition and monopoly

section: Section 4: Market Structure and Market Failure
objective: Identify situations where the market mechanism fails to allocate resources efficiently.
content: Study of externalities, public goods, and merit/demerit goods. Analyzes government intervention to correct market failure.
specific_objectives: Define 'Market Failure'
Explain the difference between private costs/benefits and social costs/benefits
Analyze positive and negative externalities with examples
Distinguish between public goods and private goods (non-excludability and non-rivalry)
Define 'merit goods' and 'demerit goods'
Evaluate government methods to correct market failure (taxes, subsidies, regulation)

objective: Explain the role of money and financial institutions in an economy.
content: Functions and qualities of money. Roles of Commercial Banks, Central Banks, and other financial intermediaries.
specific_objectives: Define 'Money' and identify its functions (medium of exchange, store of value, etc.)
List the qualities of good money (durability, portability, etc.)
Analyze the role and functions of Commercial Banks (credit creation, accepting deposits)
Describe the functions of the Central Bank (lender of last resort, issuing currency, monetary policy)
Identify other financial institutions (credit unions, insurance companies, stock exchange)

section: Section 6: Economic Management: Policies and Goals
objective: Measure and analyze the performance of the national economy.
content: National income accounting (GDP, GNP), inflation, and unemployment. Focuses on the causes and consequences of these variables.
specific_objectives: Define Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and Gross National Product (GNP)
Explain the circular flow of income
Define 'Inflation' and distinguish between cost-push and demand-pull inflation
Analyze the impact of high inflation on an economy
Define 'Unemployment' and identify its types (structural, frictional, cyclical, seasonal)
Analyze the consequences of high unemployment

section: Section 6: Economic Management: Policies and Goals
objective: Evaluate how governments manage the economy.
content: Detailed study of Fiscal Policy and Monetary Policy. Analyzes the use of budgets, taxation, and interest rates.
specific_objectives: Define 'Fiscal Policy'
Distinguish between direct and indirect taxes
Explain the concepts of budget deficit, budget surplus, and balanced budget
Define 'Monetary Policy' and its tools (interest rates, open market operations, reserve requirements)
Evaluate the effectiveness of policies in achieving economic growth and price stability

objective: Explain why nations trade and the impact of trade barriers.
content: Concepts of absolute and comparative advantage. Analyzes free trade versus protectionism.
specific_objectives: Explain the concept of 'Absolute Advantage'
Explain the theory of 'Comparative Advantage'
List the benefits of international trade
Identify and explain trade barriers (tariffs, quotas, embargoes, subsidies)
Evaluate the arguments for and against protectionism

subsection: Balance of Payments and Exchange Rates
objective: Analyze international financial transactions.
content: Structure of the Balance of Payments (BOP). Determination of exchange rates and their impact on trade.
specific_objectives: Define the 'Balance of Payments' (BOP)
Describe the components of the Current Account and the Capital/Financial Account
Distinguish between a BOP deficit and a BOP surplus
Explain how floating and fixed exchange rates are determined
Analyze the effects of currency appreciation and depreciation on imports and exports

section: Section 8: Caribbean Economies in a Global Environment
objective: Analyze the challenges and opportunities facing Caribbean economies.
content: Regional institutions like CARICOM and CSME. Impact of globalization, e-commerce, and multinational corporations.
specific_objectives: Describe the objectives and functions of CARICOM
Explain the purpose of the Caribbean Single Market and Economy (CSME)
Identify the roles of the Caribbean Development Bank (CDB) and the OECS
Define 'Globalization' and discuss its impact on small Caribbean island states
Explain the role of Multinational Corporations (MNCs) in the region
Discuss the impact of E-commerce and technology on regional trade

objective: Explain meaning conveyed through linguistic choices and structures.
content: Interpretation of meaning through word choice (formal, informal, Creole, literal, and figurative), fixed phrases, and synonyms. It includes analyzing striking word combinations such as alliteration and how they produce effective descriptions.
specific_objectives: Explain meaning conveyed in listening through word choice and grammar
Explain meaning conveyed in reading through word choice and grammar
Explain meaning conveyed through punctuation and paragraphing
Identify effective use of adjectives
Identify effective word combinations
Identify unusual turns of phrases

objective: Analyze the impact of syntax and morphology on meaning.
content: Focuses on syntax—the order and connection of words to form phrases and sentences—and morphology, which examines how the forms of words and fixed phrases change to affect meaning.
specific_objectives: Identify the ways in which words are ordered and connected to form phrases
Identify sentence structures with particular meaning
Analyze the form of words and fixed phrases
Analyze how changes made to word forms affect meaning

objective: Evaluate the effects of punctuation and paragraphing.
content: Recognition of standard punctuation marks and their specific effects on meaning. Assessment of how material is ordered in paragraphs to assist user understanding and create specific emphasis.
specific_objectives: Recognize punctuation marks including capital letters, question marks, and exclamation marks
Identify the effect of full stops, semi-colons, commas, and colons
Analyze the use of apostrophes, quotation marks, brackets, dashes, hyphens, and ellipsis
Recognize the ordering of material into paragraphs
Analyze paragraphing for specific emphases and effects

objective: Extract and interpret information accurately from various media.
content: Literal and inferential comprehension of facts, time sequences, and cause-effect relationships. It involves treating informative (expository) passages differently from literary ones and interpreting non-verbal data like charts and symbols.
specific_objectives: Recognise facts stated explicitly
Extract specific information from what is read or heard
Extract implied information by reading between the lines
Identify stated or implied time sequence
Draw valid conclusions and inferences from presented information
Recognise cause-effect relationships
Identify main and subordinate ideas and trace their development
Recognise the difference between denotative and connotative language
Identify passages where the main purpose is informative as opposed to literary or argumentative
Interpret and respond to tables and pictorial communication

objective: Grasp insights and appreciate the author's craft in literature.
content: Deducing motives and perspectives while appreciating the use of tone, mood, register, and style. Includes detecting connotations and the apt use of literary devices like irony and symbolism in West Indian and other literatures.
specific_objectives: Deduce reasons and motives for particular spoken and written communication
Appreciate the appropriateness of tone, mood, register, code, and style
Detect connotations in the use of words and presentation of ideas
Distinguish between connotative and denotative meaning
Detect and assess the apt use of devices such as pun, innuendo, exaggeration, irony, and symbolism
Recognise and respond to the appropriateness of the medium (form and structure)
Visualise the situation, attitudes, mood, and setting of a play
Recognise implicit themes
Respond to West Indian and other literature in English
Relate critical appraisal of literature to everyday living

objective: Recognise and evaluate opinions expressed in various forms.
content: Distinguishing between verifiable facts and unsupported opinions. Evaluation of persuasive techniques used in mass media and social interaction, including rhetorical questions, hyperbole, and appeals to emotion.
specific_objectives: Distinguish factual statements from unsupported opinion statements
Detect bias or particular perspective in the choice of words and evidence
Evaluate the effectiveness of language devices used to persuade
Recognise the range of techniques of persuasion employed in social intercourse and mass media
Assess the argumentative effects of persuasive techniques

objective: Apply appropriate diction and grammatical forms in communication.
content: Selection of words to influence style and match the purpose, situation, and audience. Adjusting grammatical forms for accuracy in number, concord, and tense sequence in both simple and compound sentences.
specific_objectives: Use appropriate diction to influence style
Match word choice to purpose, situation, and audience
Use accurate words, fixed phrases, synonyms, and antonyms
Adjust grammatical forms for flexibility and accuracy
Apply correct rules for subject-verb concord and pronoun reference
Use correct possessives and sequence of tenses
Use appropriate punctuation marks to convey meaning
Organize continuous writing into coherent paragraphs
Use conventions of paragraphing in writing dialogue

objective: Communicate factual information clearly and concisely.
content: Producing objective and well-organized reports, summaries, and instructions. Requires the selection of relevant main ideas and the use of appropriate register for the intended listener or reader.
specific_objectives: Give clear oral and written instructions
Write objective, accurate, and well-organized reports
Create summaries that preserve the intention of the original
Write expositions with supporting evidence for each element
Use appropriate register (formality) for the audience
Generate and arrange ideas through the process writing approach

objective: Derive aesthetic satisfaction through creative and imaginative writing.
content: Organizing ideas to communicate emotional interpretations of experience. Utilizing literary devices like metaphors and similes and choosing language suited to different characters and contexts.
specific_objectives: Organize and sequence ideas to communicate emotional interpretations
Apply imaginative slants to personal or imagined experiences
Use various literary devices (metaphor, simile, idiom) to contribute to meaning
Demonstrate the ability to interpret creative works at various levels
Use language, tone, and style appropriate to particular situations
Produce rhymes, chants, songs, or verses of poetry

objective: Communicate personal opinion clearly and cogently.
content: Developing logical arguments based on facts and evidence. Employs argumentative techniques for emotional impact and involves researching topics from different perspectives to express informed opinions.
specific_objectives: Present reasoned evaluative comments on proposals and situations
Draw conclusions logically on the basis of facts
Employ a range of argumentative techniques for emotional impact
Present logical arguments using justifiable techniques for debate
Research topics from different angles to express informed opinions
Critically analyse issues of public attention and differentiate between information and propaganda

objective: Understand and analyze drama as a discrete literary genre.
content: Focuses on elements unique to drama, specifically performance, stage directions, and the technical aspects of the stage that develop character, theme, and atmosphere.
specific_objectives: Analyze performance as the main vehicle of drama
Interpret the function of stage directions
Examine characterization within a dramatic context
Evaluate the role of spectacle in a play
Analyze the use of lighting, costuming, and stage props to develop theme

objective: Understand and analyze poetry as a discrete literary genre.
content: Exploration of poetic forms and the technical relationship between sound and sense. Focuses on the economy of language and the levels of meaning provided by figurative devices.
specific_objectives: Identify fixed forms, metre, rhythm, and rhyme
Analyze the economy of language in poetic expression
Examine the organic relationship between sound and sense
Evaluate figurative language used to create levels of meaning

objective: Understand and analyze elements of the novel and short story.
content: Analysis of narrative techniques, structure, and the presentation of social settings. Focuses on the expansive nature of prose and how narration differs from description.
specific_objectives: Analyze narrative techniques including first-person and third-person narrators
Evaluate the structure of prose works (unbroken vs. episodic)
Distinguish between narration and description
Examine the presentation of humankind in social settings
Analyze characterization and themes in prose fiction

objective: Understand the structure and assessment criteria of the English A exam.
content: The examination consists of three papers: Paper 01 (Multiple Choice), Paper 02 (Free Response), and Paper 031 (SBA) or Paper 032 (Alternative). Paper 01 assesses Understanding Profile 1, while Paper 02 and the SBA/Alternative assess both Understanding and Expression profiles.
specific_objectives: Complete 60 multiple-choice items in Paper 01 based on poems, literary extracts, and visual stimuli
Provide written responses to four sections in Paper 02: Summary, Exposition, Short Story, and Argumentative Essay
Demonstrate competency in communicating factual information concisely in Section B of Paper 02
Construct a short story based on optional prompts in Section C of Paper 02
Develop a logical argumentative essay in Section D of Paper 02

objective: Understand the structure and assessment criteria of the English B exam.
content: Assessment is distributed across three components: Paper 01 (Multiple Choice), Paper 02 (Extended Essay), and Paper 031 (SBA) or Paper 032 (Alternative). Paper 01 focuses on 20 questions per genre (Drama, Poetry, Prose Fiction), while Paper 02 requires in-depth analytical essays on prescribed texts.
specific_objectives: Complete 60 multiple-choice questions covering Caribbean and other literature in Paper 01
Answer two Type A questions on prescribed Drama texts in Section A of Paper 02
Answer Type B comparison questions on prescribed Poetry in Section B of Paper 02
Respond to either a novel or short stories in Section C of Paper 02 using analytical or comparative formats
Demonstrate the use of the vocabulary of literary criticism in written responses

objective: Produce a comprehensive research portfolio and oral presentation.
content: A single SBA portfolio is used for both English A and English B. It is a social and cognitive task where students work in groups but are assessed on individual components like a Plan of Investigation, Reflections, and an Oral Presentation, alongside a group Written Report.
specific_objectives: Draft a Plan of Investigation of no more than 100 words explaining the choice of topic
Collect a minimum of three pieces of material (print, audio, visual) related to the group topic
Complete three reflection entries discussing how materials shaped thinking and the use of language
Collaborate on a group Written Report (250-300 words) summarizing research outcomes
Deliver a 3 to 5-minute Oral Presentation in a chosen genre using Standard English

objective: Analyze specific literary works required for the English B examination.
content: Prescribed works include classic and modern drama alongside a curated list of poems from 'A World of Poetry'. These texts form the basis for Section A and B of Paper 02.
specific_objectives: Analyze 'The Tempest' by William Shakespeare
Analyze 'Ti-Jean and his Brothers' by Derek Walcott
Interpret themes in 'An African Thunderstorm' by David Rubadiri
Evaluate the craft in 'Dreaming Black Boy' by James Berry
Compare 'Dulce et Decorum Est' by Wilfred Owen with other prescribed poems

objective: Analyze specific novels and short stories required for the English B examination.
content: Students must study designated novels and a collection of ten short stories from 'A World of Prose'. Assessment focuses on narrative technique, characterization, and setting.
specific_objectives: Analyze the novel 'Breath, Eyes, Memory' by Edwidge Danticat
Analyze the novel 'To Kill a Mockingbird' by Harper Lee
Evaluate short stories including 'The Two Grandmothers' by Olive Senior
Interpret conflict in 'Blackout' by Roger Mais
Analyze themes of childhood in 'The Boy Who Loved Ice Cream'

objective: Correctly interpret instructional verbs used in examination questions.
content: Definitions of operational verbs used in CXC English A and B papers to ensure candidates meet specific cognitive requirements in their answers.
specific_objectives: Apply the 'Compare' instruction by examining similarities and differences to reach a conclusion
Execute 'Describe' tasks by providing detailed accounts of significant characteristics
Perform 'Discuss' tasks by exploring related concepts and issues using detailed examples
Respond to 'Comment' by examining elements to create effect and explaining the writer's purpose
Summarize information by presenting main points and concepts in one's own words

objective: Assess research and analytical skills for non-school candidates.
content: A 2-hour paper for private candidates consisting of a guided critique of three stimulus materials, including a newspaper article, a cartoon/song, and a poem/short story.
specific_objectives: Respond to questions on issues raised in the stimulus and impact on the audience
Analyze language techniques used in given stimulus materials
Demonstrate awareness of the characteristic features of an oral presentation
Create a personal imaginative response in the form of drama, poetry, or prose

objective: Interpret and respond to visual and graphic stimuli.
content: Analysis of non-verbal communication including advertisements, cartoons, maps, and statistical data. Understanding how visual elements complement or contrast with textual information.
specific_objectives: Interpret elements of design in advertisements (layout, color, font)
Analyze the use of symbolism in political cartoons
Extract data from charts, graphs, and tables accurately
Identify the persuasive intent behind visual choices in media
Synthesize visual and verbal information to form a holistic understanding

objective: Produce formal and semi-formal workplace communications.
content: Writing based on specific scenarios including minutes of meetings, letters of application, and formal reports. Focuses on clarity, professional tone, and adherence to standard formats.
specific_objectives: Write accurate minutes of meetings following a standard format
Draft formal letters of complaint, application, and inquiry
Construct incident reports with objective and chronological details
Use appropriate salutations and closings for different audiences
Apply the 'concise and precise' principle in technical communication

objective: Analyze the function of figurative language and sound devices.
content: Deep dive into the 'mechanics' of poetry and prose. Understanding how sound, imagery, and structure work together to create meaning and impact.
specific_objectives: Differentiate between simile, metaphor, and personification
Analyze sound devices: alliteration, sibilance, onomatopoeia, and assonance
Identify rhetorical devices: oxymoron, paradox, hyperbole, and litotes
Evaluate the effect of enjambment and caesura in poetic rhythm
Examine the use of motifs and extended metaphors across a text

objective: Evaluate the architectural components of prose fiction.
content: Advanced analysis of storytelling techniques beyond simple plot summary. Focuses on the author's manipulation of time, perspective, and internal psychology.
specific_objectives: Analyze the impact of different points of view (first, second, third person)
Identify use of stream of consciousness and internal monologue
Examine chronological vs. non-linear narrative structures (flashbacks, foreshadowing)
Evaluate the function of setting as a 'character' or symbolic force
Deconstruct character development (flat vs. round, static vs. dynamic)

objective: Analyze the technical elements of the stage and performance.
content: Understanding drama as a performance medium. Focuses on the conventions that allow the playwright to communicate directly with the audience.
specific_objectives: Analyze the function of soliloquy and aside in character revelation
Identify types of irony: situational, verbal, and dramatic
Examine the role of the chorus or narrator in classical and modern drama
Evaluate the impact of costuming, lighting, and stage blocking on theme
Distinguish between internal and external conflict in dramatic action

objective: Master the conventions of Standard Caribbean English.
content: Comprehensive focus on the mechanics of writing that underpin both English A and English B. Covers the structural integrity of sentences and paragraphs.
specific_objectives: Apply rules of subject-verb agreement in complex sentences
Correct comma splices, run-on sentences, and fragments
Use capital letters and basic punctuation with 100% accuracy
Identify and correct common spelling errors and homophones
Maintain consistent tense and pronoun reference throughout a piece of writing

section: Section 1: Practical Skills and Field Study
objective: Develop skills in map interpretation and analysis.
content: Grid references, scales, contour lines, and identifying physical and human features.
specific_objectives: Convert between types of scales (statement, ratio, linear)
Identify features using 4-figure and 6-figure grid references
Calculate area, gradient, and distance on a topographic map
Interpret relief using contour lines and cross-sections
Differentiate between physical features and land-use patterns

objective: Analyze the physical forces that shape the Earth.
content: Plate tectonics, volcanic activity, earthquakes, and the rock cycle.
specific_objectives: Explain the theory of Plate Tectonics and types of plate boundaries
Identify the causes and effects of volcanic eruptions and earthquakes
Describe the stages of the rock cycle (Igneous, Sedimentary, Metamorphic)
Analyze the process of weathering (chemical and mechanical) and mass wasting
Discuss the formation and significance of various landforms (rivers, coasts, limestone)

objective: Explain the mechanics of weather and the impact of climate.
